source.query: push up with sandbag drag muscles worked
source.raw_text:
The Push-Up with Sandbag Drag is a compound, full-body exercise that blends pushing (chest, shoulders, triceps) with anti-rotation and core stabilization (abs, obliques, lower back) and hip/leg engagement (glutes, hamstrings) to build power, core strength, and stability, progressing towards single-arm push-ups by challenging the body to maintain a rigid plank while shifting load laterally. It combines a standard push-up (pushing pattern) with a plank lateral drag (stabilization/anti-rotation pattern), targeting chest, shoulders, triceps, core, lats, and hips. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Pushing): Chest (Pectorals), Shoulders (Deltoids), Triceps. 
• Stabilizers/Core: Core (Transverse Abdominis, Obliques), Lower Back, Serratus Anterior. 
• Dynamic Stabilizers (Drag): Glutes, Hamstrings, Lats, Forearms (for grip). [1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]  

This video demonstrates how to perform a sandbag lateral drag: 
Movement Patterns 

• Pushing: The standard push-up portion involves elbow flexion and extension (pushing) to move the body up and down. 
• Anti-Rotation/Stabilization: The drag requires significant anti-rotation, where the core and supporting shoulder/hip resist the bag's shifting weight, preventing hip or torso rotation. 
• Pulling/Scapular Movement (Drag): Reaching and pulling the bag engages the lats and challenges shoulder stability. 
• Full-Body Integration: Connects the core to the limbs, building functional strength for real-life movements by training the body to move as a unit, notes BrickHouse Nutrition (https://brickhousenutrition.com/blogs/articles/sandbag-training-101-is-this-the-ultimate-full-body-workout-tool) and Ultimate Sandbag Training (https://ultimatesandbagtraining.com/10-ultimate-sandbag-exercises-that-are-musts/). [1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9]  

This video shows a variation of the exercise with a dumbbell: 
How It Works (The Drag) 

1. Start: Begin in a high plank with your feet wide and the sandbag beside one hand. 
2. Reach & Drag: Reach across your body with the opposite hand, grab the bag, and slowly drag it under your torso to the other side, keeping hips level and core tight. 
3. Push-Up: As the bag crosses, lower into a one-arm push-up, then press back up, maintaining tension. 
4. Alternate: Repeat the drag and push-up on the other side, creating a powerful, unstable workout. [1, 4, 9, 10]
